(1) The obligation of sponsors and fidepromissors did not descend to their heirs, Gaius iii. 120. (2) By a lex Publilia oi uncertain date a sponsor who paid the debt could, unless repaid by the principal within six months, recover twice the amount by actio depensi, Gaius iv. 22. (3) The lex Furia de sponsu, circ. tte 95 (which, however, extended only to Italy), limited the liability oi sponsors and fidepromissors to two years from the date of their contract, and also (4) where there were two or more of them, divided the liability among all who were living at the time when the guarantee could be ensorced, so that each could be sued sor only an aliquot share, Gaius iii. 121. (5) The lex Apuleia, tac 102 (extending also to the provinces), conlerred a less but similar boon on sponsors and fidepromissors even outside Italy, by giving to any one orthem who paid the whole debt an actio pro socio against the rest, by which he could recover what he had paid in excess of his lair share, Gaius iii. 122. (6) A statute whose name is illegible in the MS. oi Gaius, iii. 123 (Cicereia, Rudoril), provided that a creditor, on taking sponsors or iidepromissors, should first state openly what the debt to be guaranteed was, and also the number os sureties he was going to take ; if this were not done, they could by taking action within thirty days procure their release. Gaius says that this enactment had by usage been extended to fideiussors also, but it was obsolete under Justinian.

Fideiussio, like sponsio and fidepromissio, is a formos what is called cumulative intercession, which may be defined as a contract between a creditor and a third person by which the latter takes upon himself the debtor's obligation without the debtor being himself released.
